newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: MOZAMBIQUE OPENS ARMS TO FREE MARKET.
newsitem.headline: MOZAMBIQUE OPENS ARMS TO FREE MARKET.

text.p: The Southern African country of Mozambique said on Wednesday that it was opening its arms to the free market.
The country has been wracked by decades of war between its once-avowedly communist government and right-wing rebels.
But prime minister Pascoal Mocumbi said the only way forward for the country, which has now enjoyed two years of peace, was to embrace free market principles.

"Mozambique will have to work hand in hand with the private sector. It is partnership between the government and the private sector that will ensure success," he told the Southern African Trade and Investment Summit being held in Harare.
Mozambique is rich in natural resources that have been largely untapped because of the war. Of its 10 million hectares of arable land, only about one fifth is being exploited.
The country also has substantial coal, mineral and gas resources.
"After years of conflict our region today is at peace...Mozambique is a viable destination for investment in Southern Africa," Mocumbi said.
